hints.content:
There's a lot of good thinking in Bennett's work. He can keep an expression equal and still break apart or group the factors.

Let's find where Bennett changed the value of the expression.

###Step 1

$\redE{90}\times3 \overset{\checkmark}{=} \redE{10 \times 9}\times3$

Bennett broke apart the factors of ${90}$ correctly.

###Step 2

$\begin{align}
90\times{3} &=10\times  \blueE{9\times 3}\\\\
&=10 \times \blueE{27}\\\\
&\neq 10 + \blueE{27}
\end{align}$

Bennett grouped the factors $10$ and $9$ correctly but did *not* use the right operation to combine.
Bennett made a mistake in step $2$.
